Function.Name: SQUANTILE
Function.Definition: Returns the quantile from a distribution when you specify the right probability (SDF).
Function.Description1:
Is a character constant, variable, or expression that identifies the distribution. Valid distributions are as follows:

      Bernoulli distribution: 'BERNOULLI'
      Beta distribution: 'BETA'
      Binomial distribution: 'BINOMIAL'
      Cauchy distribution: 'CAUCHY'
      Chi-Square distribution: 'CHISQUARE'
      Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution: 'CMP'
      Exponential distribution: 'EXPONENTIAL'
      F distribution: 'F'
      Gamma distribution: 'GAMMA'
      Generalized Poisson distribution: 'GENPOISSON'
      Geometric distribution: 'GEOMETRIC'
      Hypergeometric distribution: 'HYPERGEOMETRIC'
      Laplace distribution: 'LAPLACE'
      Logistic distribution: 'LOGISTIC'
      Lognormal'LOGNORMAL'
      Negative binomial distribution: 'NEGBINOMIAL'
      Normal distribution: 'NORMAL'|'GAUSS'
      Normal mixture distribution: 'NORMALMIX'
      Pareto distribution: 'PARETO'
      Poisson distribution: 'POISSON'
      T distribution: 'T'
      Tweedie distribution: 'TWEEDIE').
      Uniform distribution: 'UNIFORM'
      Wald (inverse Gaussian) distribution: 'WALD'|'IGAUSS'
      Weibull distribution: 'WEIBULL'

      Note: Except for T, F, and NORMALMIX, you can minimally identify any distribution by its first four characters.
Function.Description2: Is a numeric constant, variable, or expression that specifies the value of a random variable.
Function.Description3: Are optional shape, location, or scale parameters that are appropriate for the specific distribution.

Function.Name: SYSEXIST
Function.Definition: Returns a value that indicates whether an operating-environment variable exists in your environment.
Function.Description1: Specifies a character variable that is the name of an operating-environment variable that you want to test.

Function.Name: TIMEVALUE
Function.Definition: Returns the equivalent of a reference amount at a base date by using variable interest rates.
Function.Description1: Is a SAS date. The value that is returned is the time value of reference-amount at base-date.
Function.Description2: Is a SAS date. reference-date is the date of reference-amount.
Function.Description3: Is numeric. reference-amount is the amount at reference-date.
Function.Description4: Is a SAS interval. compounding-interval is the compounding interval.
Function.Description5: Is a SAS date. Each date is paired with a rate. date is the time that rate takes effect.
Function.Description6: Is a numeric percentage. Each rate is paired with a date. rate is the interest rate that starts on date.
Function.Description7: Optional additional date-rate pairs(s)

Function.Name: ADDMATRIX
Function.Definition: Performs an elementwise addition of two matrices or a matrix and a scalar.
Function.Description1: Specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x n (that is, X[m, n]) or a scalar.
Function.Description2: Specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x n (that is, Y[m, n]) or a scalar.
Function.Description3: Specifies an output matrix with dimensions m x n (that is, Z[m, n]), such that Z = X + Y.

Function.Name: CHOL
Function.Definition: Calculates the Cholesky decomposition for a given symmetric matrix.
Function.Description1: Specifies a symmetric positive-definite input matrix with dimensions m x m (that is, X[m, m]).
Function.Description2:
Specifies an output matrix with dimensions m x m (that is, Y[m, m]). This variable contains the Cholesky decomposition, such that 

  Z= YY*
  
where Y is a lower triangular matrix with strictly positive diagonal entries and 
Y* denotes the conjugate transpose of Y. 

Note: If X is not symmetric positive-definite, then Y will be filled with missing values.
Function.Description3:
Specifies an optional argument that can increase the processing speed by avoiding error checking. The argument can take the following values: 

  0 the matrix X will be checked for symmetry. This is the default if the validate 
    argument is omitted.  
  1 the matrix is assumed to be symmetric.

Function.Name: DET
Function.Definition: Calculates the determinant of a specified matrix that should be square.
Function.Description1: Specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x n (that is, X[m, m]).
Function.Description2: Specifies the returned determinate value, such that a = |X|.

Function.Name: DYNAMIC_ARRAY
Function.Definition: Enables an array that is declared within a function to change size in an efficient manner.
Function.Description1: Specifies the name of a temporary array.
Function.Description2: Specifies a new size for the temporary array.

Function.Name: ELEMMULT
Function.Definition: Performs an elementwise multiplication of two matrices.
Function.Description1: Specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x n (that is, X[m, n]).
Function.Description2: Specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x n (that is, Y[m, n]).
Function.Description3: Specifies an output matrix with dimensions m x n (that is, Z[m, n]).

Function.Name: EXPMATRIX
Function.Definition: Returns a matrix e**tA given the input matrix A and a multiplier t.
Function.Description1: Specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x m (that is, X[m, m]).
Function.Description2: Specifies a double scalar value.
Function.Description3: Specifies an output matrix with dimensions m x m (that is, Y[m, m]), such that Y = Ԑ**tẊ where Ẋ is the mean of X.

Function.Name: FILLMATRIX
Function.Definition: Replaces all of the element values of the input matrix with the specified value.
Function.Description1: Specifies an input numeric matrix.
Function.Description2: Specifies the numeric value that will fill the matrix.

Function.Name: IDENTITY
Function.Definition: Converts the input matrix to an identity matrix.
Function.Description1: Specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x m (that is, X[m, m]).

Function.Name: INV
Function.Definition: Calculates a matrix that is the inverse of the provided input matrix that should be a square, non-singular matrix.
Function.Description1: specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x m (that is, X[m, m]).
Function.Description2:
Specifies an output matrix with dimensions m x m (that is, Y[m, m]), such that 
  
    Y[m.m] = X'[m,m]

  where ' denotes inverse 
  
    X x Y = Y x X = I
  
and I is the identity matrix.

Function.Name: MULT
Function.Definition: Calculates the multiplicative product of two input matrices.
Function.Description1: Specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x n (that is, X[m, n]).
Function.Description2: Specifies an input matrix with dimensions n x p (that is, Y[n, p]).
Function.Description3:
Specifies an output matrix with dimensions m x p (that is, Z[m, p]), such that 

    Z[m,p] = X[m,n] x Y[n,p]

Function.Name: POWER
Function.Definition: Raises a square matrix to a given scalar value.
Function.Description1: Specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x m (that is, X[m, m]).
Function.Description2: Specifies an integer scalar value (power).
Function.Description3:
Specifies an output matrix with dimensions m x m (that is, Y[m, m]), such that 
    
    Y = X**a

Function.Name: SETNULL
Function.Definition: Sets a pointer element of a structure to null.
Function.Description1: Is a pointer to a structure

Function.Name: STRUCTINDEX
Function.Definition: Enables you to access each structure element in an array of structures.
Function.Description1: Specifies an array.
Function.Description2: Is a 1–based index as used in most SAS arrays.
Function.Description3: Points to an element in the array.

Function.Name: SUBTRACTMATRIX
Function.Definition: Performs an element-wide subtraction of two matrices or a matrix and a scalar.
Function.Description1: specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x n (that is, X[m, n]) or a scalar.
Function.Description2: specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x n (that is, Y[m, n]) or a scalar.
Function.Description3:
specifies an output matrix with dimensions m x n (that is, Z[m, n]), such that 

    Z = X - Y

Function.Name: TRANSPOSE
Function.Definition: Returns the transpose of a matrix.
Function.Description1: Specifies an input matrix with dimensions m x n (that is, X[m, n]).
Function.Description2: Specifies an output matrix with dimensions n x m (that is, Y[n, m]).

Function.Name: ZEROMATRIX
Function.Definition: Replaces all of the element values of the numeric input matrix with 0.
Function.Description1: Specifies a numeric input matrix.

Function.Name: INVCDF
Function.Definition: Computes the quantile from any distribution for which you have defined a cumulative distribution function (CDF).
Function.Description2:
Specifies an array of options to use with the INVCDF function. Options-array is used to 
control and monitor the process of inverting the CDF. Options-array can be a missing value (.), 
or it can have up to four of the following elements in the following order: 

  initial-value 
    specifies the initial guess for the quantile at which the inversion process starts. This is 
    useful when you have an idea of the approximate value for quantile. The default for initial-value is 0.1. 
  desired-accuracy 
    specifies the desired relative accuracy of the quantile. You can specify any value in the range (0,0.1).
    The default for desired-accuracy is 1.0e-8.
  domain-type 
    specifies the domain for the CDF function. A missing value or a value of 0 indicates a nonnegative 
    support, that is [0,∞). Any other value indicates a support over the entire real line, that is (-∞,∞). 
    The default for domain-type is 0. 
  return-code 
    specifies the return status. If options-array is of dimension 4 or more, then the fourth element contains 
    the return status. Return-code can have one of the following values: 
      <=0 
        indicates success. If negative, then the absolute value is the number of times the CDF function was 
        evaluated in order to compute the quantile. A larger absolute value indicates longer convergence time. 
      1 
        indicates that the quantile could not be computed.
Function.Description3: Specifies the cumulative probability value for which the quantile is desired. This must be in the range [0,1).
Function.Description4: Specifies the parameters of the distribution at which the quantile is desired. You must specify exactly the same number of parameters as required by the specified CDF function, and they should appear exactly in the same order as required by the specified CDF function.

Function.Name: ISNULL
Function.Definition: Determines whether a pointer element of a structure is null.
Function.Description1: Specifies a variable that contains the address of another variable.

Function.Name: LIMMOMENT
Function.Definition: Computes the limited moment of any distribution for which you have defined a cumulative distribution function (CDF).
Function.Description2:
Specifies an array of options to use with the INVCDF function. Options-array is used to 
control and monitor the process of inverting the CDF. Options-array can be a missing value (.), 
or it can have up to four of the following elements in the following order: 

  initial-value 
    specifies the initial guess for the quantile at which the inversion process starts. This is 
    useful when you have an idea of the approximate value for quantile. The default for initial-value is 0.1. 
  desired-accuracy 
    specifies the desired relative accuracy of the quantile. You can specify any value in the range (0,0.1).
    The default for desired-accuracy is 1.0e-8.
  domain-type 
    specifies the domain for the CDF function. A missing value or a value of 0 indicates a nonnegative 
    support, that is [0,∞). Any other value indicates a support over the entire real line, that is (-∞,∞). 
    The default for domain-type is 0. 
  return-code 
    specifies the return status. If options-array is of dimension 4 or more, then the fourth element contains 
    the return status. Return-code can have one of the following values: 
      <=0 
        indicates success. If negative, then the absolute value is the number of times the CDF function was 
        evaluated in order to compute the quantile. A larger absolute value indicates longer convergence time. 
      1 
        indicates that the quantile could not be computed.
Function.Description3: Specifies the order of the desired limited moment. This value must be in the range [1,10].
Function.Description4: Specifies the upper limit that is used to compute the desired limited moment. This value must be greater than 0.
Function.Description5: Specifies the parameters of the distribution at which the limited moment is desired. You must specify exactly the same number of parameters as required by the specified CDF function, and they should appear exactly in the same order as required by the specified CDF function.

Function.Name: READ_ARRAY
Function.Definition: Reads data from a SAS data set into a PROC FCMP array variable.
Function.Description1: Specifies the name of the data set from which the array data will be read. data_set_name must be a character literal or variable that contains the member name (libname.memname) of the data set to be read from.
Function.Description2: specifies the PROC FCMP array variable into which the data is read. array_variable must be a local temporary array variable because the function might need to grow or shrink its size to accommodate the size of the data set.
Function.Description3:
Specifies optional names for the specific columns of the data set that will be read. 

If specified, col_name must be a literal string enclosed in quotation marks. col_name cannot be a PROC FCMP variable. If column names are not specified, PROC FCMP reads all of the columns in the data set.

Function.Name: RUN_MACRO(, );
Function.Definition: Executes a predefined SAS macro.
Function.Description1:
specifies the name of the macro to be run. 
    
Requirement:macro_name must be a string enclosed in quotation marks or a character variable that contains the macro to be executed.
Function.Description2:
Specifies optional PROC FCMP variables, which are set by macro variables of the same name. These arguments must be PROC FCMP double or character variables. 

Before SAS executes the macro, SAS macro variables are defined with the same name and value as the PROC FCMP variables. After SAS executes the macro, the macro variable values are copied back to the corresponding PROC FCMP variables.

Function.Name: RUN_SASFILE
Function.Definition: Executes SAS code in a fileref that you specify.
Function.Description1:
Specifies the name of the SAS fileref that points to the SAS code. 
    
Requirement:fileref_name must be a string enclosed in quotation marks or a character variable that contains the name of the SAS fileref.
Function.Description2:
Specifies optional PROC FCMP variables that will be set by macro variables of the same name. These arguments must be PROC FCMP double or character variables. 

Before SAS executes the code that references the SAS file, the SAS macro variables are defined with the same name and value as the PROC FCMP variables. After execution, these macro variable values are copied back to the corresponding PROC FCMP variables.

Function.Name: SOLVE
Function.Definition: Computes implicit values of a function.
Function.Description1: Specifies the name of the function. Enclose function-name in quotation marks.
Function.Description2:
Specifies an array of options to use with the SOLVE function. Options-array is used to control and 
monitor the root-finding process. Options-array can be a missing value (.), or it can have up to five 
of the following elements in the following order:   

  initial-value 
    specifies the starting value for the implied value. The default for the first call is 0.001. If 
    the same line of code is executed again, then options-array uses the previously found implied value. 
  absolute-criterion 
    specifies a value for convergence. The absolute value of the difference between the expected value 
    and the predicted value must be less than the value of absolute-criterion for convergence. 
    Default:1.0e–12 
  relative-criterion 
    specifies a value for convergence. When the change in the computed implied value is less than the 
    value of relative-criterion, then convergence is assumed. 
    Default:1.0e–6 
  maximum-iterations 
    specifies the maximum number of iterations to use to find the solution. 
    Default:100 
  solve-status 
    can be one of the following values: 
      0 successful. 
      1 could not decrease the error. 
      2 could not compute a change vector. 
      3 maximum number of iterations exceeded. 
      4 initial objective function is missing.
Function.Description3: Specifies the expected value of the function of interest.
Function.Description4: Specifies the arguments to pass to the function that is being minimized.

Function.Name: WRITE_ARRAY
Function.Definition: Writes data from a PROC FCMP array variable to a data set that can then be used by SAS programs, macros, and procedures.
Function.Description1: Specifies the name of the data set to which the array data will be written. data_set_name must be a character literal or variable that contains the member name (libname.memname) of the data set to be created.
Function.Description2: Specifies the PROC FCMP array or matrix variable whose contents will be written to data_set_name.
Function.Description3:
Specifies optional names for the columns of the data set that will be created. 

If specified, col_name must be a literal string enclosed in quotation marks. col_name cannot be a PROC FCMP variable. If column names are not specified, the column name will be the array name with a numeric suffix.

Function.Name: INSERT_CATALOG
Function.Definition: Inserts a SAS catalog into a package.
Function.Description1:
Identifies the package into which the catalog will be inserted. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description2:
Names the library that contains the catalog. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description3:
Specifies the name of the catalog. 
    
Type: Character
Function.Description4:
Describes the catalog. 
    
Type: Character
Function.Description5:
Identifies a list of one or more space-separated name/value pairs, each in one of the following forms:

      name
      name=value
      name="value"
      name="single value with spaces"
      name=(value)
      name=("value")
      name=(value1, "value 2", ... valueN)

Name/value pairs are site-specific; they are used for the purpose of filtering.
Function.Description6:
Receives a return code. 
    
Type: Numeric.

Function.Name: INSERT_DATASET
Function.Definition: Inserts a SAS data set into a package.
Function.Description1:
Identifies the package into which the data set will be inserted. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description2:
Names the library that contains the data set. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description3:
Specifies the name of the data set. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description4:
Describes the data set. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description5:
Identifies a list of one or more space-separated name/value pairs, each in one of the following forms:

      name
      name=value
      name="value"
      name="single value with spaces"
      name=(value)
      name=("value")
      name=(value1, "value 2", ... valueN)

Name/value pairs are site-specific; they are used for the purpose of filtering.
Function.Description6:
Receives a return code. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description7:
Identifies a comma-separated list of optional property names. Valid property names are as follows:

      ALLOW_READ_PROTECTED_MEMBER
      DATASET_OPTIONS
      TRANSFORMATION_TYPE
      CSV_SEPARATOR
      CSV_FLAG

Type: Character
Function.Description8:
Specifies one value for each specified property. The order of the values matches the order of the property names in the properties parameter. Valid property values are defined as follows:

      ALLOW_READ_PROTECTED_MEMBER
      specifies a value of "YES". It is important to note that the password and encryption 
      attributes are not preserved in the intermediate published format (whether on a queue 
      or in an archive). Because of this exposure, take care when publishing data sets that 
      are password protected, encrypted or both. 

      DATASET_OPTIONS
      specifies data set options. 

      TRANSFORMATION_TYPE
      indicates that the data set should be transformed to the specified type when published. 
      At this time, the only supported value for this property is CSV, for Comma-Separated-Value.

      CSV_SEPARATOR
      indicates the separator to use when creating the CSV file. The default separator 
      is a comma (,).

      CSV_FLAG
      indicates a CSV override flag. Supported values include NO_VARIABLES, NO_LABELS, and 
      EXTENDED. By default, when writing numeric variable values into the CSV file, BEST is 
      used to format numerics that have no format associated with them. To override this 
      default, specify the property value EXTENDED on the CSV_FLAG property. This extends 
      the number of digits used as the precision level. By default, if the data set is 
      transformed into a CSV file, then the file's first line contains all of the specified 
      variables. The second line contains all of the specified labels. To override this 
      default behavior, specify flags with values "NO_VARIABLES" or "NO_LABELS". To 
      specify both values, a CSV_FLAG property must be specified for each.

Type: Character or Numeric

Function.Name: INSERT_FDB
Definition: Inserts a financial database (FDB) into a package.
Inserts a SAS data set into a package.
Function.Description1:
Identifies the package into which the FDB will be inserted. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description2:
Names the library that contains the FDB. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description3:
Specifies the name of the FDB. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description4:
Describes the FDB. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description5:
Identifies a list of one or more space-separated name/value pairs, each in one of the following forms:

      name
      name=value
      name="value"
      name="single value with spaces"
      name=(value)
      name=("value")
      name=(value1, "value 2", ... valueN)

Name/value pairs are site-specific; they are used for the purpose of filtering.
Function.Description6: Receives a return code. Type: Numeric.

Function.Name: INSERT_FILE
Function.Definition: Inserts a file into a package.
Function.Description1:
Identifies the package into which the file will be inserted. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description2:
Names the file, using the following syntax:

      FILENAME: external_filename
      FILEREF: sas_fileref

Type: Character
Function.Description3:
Specifies the file type, which must be TEXT or BINARY. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description4:
Specifies the MIME type, the value of which is determined by the user. Subscribers can filter packages based on MIME type.

      Suggested MIME types include the following:

      application/msword
      application/octet-stream
      application/pdf
      application/postscript
      application/zip
      audio/basic
      image/jpeg
      image/gif
      image/tiff
      model/vrml
      text/html
      text/plain
      text/richtext
      video/mpeg
      video/quicktime
Function.Description5: Describes the file. Type: Character.
Function.Description6:
Identifies a list of one or more space-separated name/value pairs, each in one of the following forms:

      name
      name=value
      name="value"
      name="single value with spaces"
      name=(value)
      name=("value")
      name=(value1, "value 2", ... valueN)

      Name/value pairs are site-specific; they are used for the purpose of filtering.
Function.Description7:
Receives a return code. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description8:
Identifies a comma-separated list of optional property names. Valid property names are as follows:

    PATH

Type: Character
Function.Description9:
Specifies one value for each specified property name. The order of the property values must match the order of the property names in the properties parameter. Valid property values are defined as follows:

      PATH
      indicates the relative path information for this file. The relative path is included 
      as the name of the file when defined in the ZIP file. The specified path should not 
      contain a drive or device letter, or a leading slash. All slashes should be forward 
      slashes '/' as opposed to backslashes '\'. This property is recognized only by the 
      archive transport. It is ignored by all other transports.

Type: Character

Function.Name: INSERT_HTML
Function.Definition: Inserts HTML files into a package.
Function.Description1:
Identifies the package into which the HTML will be inserted. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description2:
Names the HTML body file, using the following syntax:

    FILEREF: SAS_fileref
    FILENAME: external_filename

Type: Character
Function.Description3:
Specifies the URL to be used for the body file.

Type: Character
Function.Description4:
Names the HTML frame file, using the following syntax:

    FILEREF: SAS_fileref
    FILENAME: external_filename

Type: Character
Function.Description5: Specifies the URL to be used for the frame file. Type: Character
Function.Description6:
Names the HTML contents file, using the following syntax:

    FILEREF: SAS_fileref
    FILENAME: external_filename

Type: Character
Function.Description7:
Specifies the URL to be used for the contents file. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description8:
Names the HTML page file, using the following syntax:

    FILEREF: SAS_fileref 
    FILENAME: external_filename

Type: Character
Function.Description9:
Specifies the URL to be used for the page file. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description10:
Describes the inserted HTML package entry. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description11: Identifies a list of one or more space-separated name/value pairs, each in the form of name=value. Name/value pairs are site-specific; they are used for the purpose of filtering.
Function.Description12:
Receives a return code. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description13:
Identifies a comma-separated list of optional property names. Valid property names are as follows:

      ENCODING
      COMPANION_FILE
      COMPANION_MIMETYPE
      COMPANION_URL
      GPATH
      GPATH_URL
      NESTED_NAME

Type: Character
Function.Description14:
Specifies one value for each specified property. The order of the values matches the order of the property names in the properties parameter. Valid property values are defined as follows:

      ENCODING
      indicates the character set of the HTML files, such as ISO-8859-1.

      COMPANION_FILE
      indicates the name of an additional HTML file that is to be added to this set of 
      HTML files. Multiple COMPANION_FILE properties and values can be specified. Name 
      the companion files, using the following syntax: FILEREF: SAS_fileref or
      FILENAME: external_filename

      COMPANION_MIMETYPE
      indicates the MIME type of the companion file that is to be added to the inserted 
      HTML entry. If specified, then this property must be preceded by the COMPANION_FILE 
      property.

      COMPANION_URL
      indicates the URL of an HTML file that is to be added to the inserted HTML entry.
      If specified, then this property must be preceded by the COMPANION_FILE property.

      GPATH
      indicates the name of a single directory that contains the ODS-generated graphical 
      files for inclusion as companion files to the HTML file set.
      
      GPATH_URL
      indicates the URL of the directory that contains the ODS-generated graphical files. 
      An example of a URL might be ~ods-output/images. Alternatively, you can specify 
      "NONE" as the GPATH_URL property value. If the value of "NONE" is specified, then 
      only the filename is used as the URL.

      NESTED_NAME
      indicates the name of the nested directory to create for the storage of the set 
      of HTML files. If you do not specify a value for this property, then a name is 
      generated automatically.

Type: Character

      name=("value")
      name=(value1, "value 2", ... valueN)

Name/value pairs are site-specific; they are used for the purpose of filtering.
Function.Description6:
Receives a return code.

    NESTED_NAME

    If you do not specify a value for this property, then a name is generated automatically. 

    Note: The NESTED_NAME property is valid only when publishing to the WebDAV-compliant 
    server transport.

Function.Name: PACKAGE_BEGIN

Identifies the new package.

Describes the package.

Identifies a list of one or more space-separated name/value pairs, each in one of the following forms:

      name
      name=value
      name="value"
      name="single value with spaces"
      name=(value)
      name=("value")
      name=(value1, "value 2", ... valueN)

Receives a return code.

Identifies a comma-separated list of optional property names. Valid property names are as follows:

    EXPIRATION_DATETIME
    NAMESPACES
    
Type: Character
Function.Description8:
Specifies one value for each specified property name. The order of the values must match the order of the property names in the properties parameter. Valid property values are defined as follows:

      ABSTRACT 
      provides an abstract (short summary) of the inserted package.

      EXPIRATION_DATETIME 
      numeric SAS datetime value. This value should be specified in GMT format. 

      NAMESPACES 
      specifies unique names that associate published packages with specific contexts 
      on a WebDAV-compliant server. The association of a namespace with a package 
      organizes package data on a server according to meaningful criteria or contexts.

Type: Character or Numeric

Identifies the package that is to be published.

Function.Description2: Indicates how to publish the package. To publish the package by using the queue transport, specify a publishType of TO_QUEUE. Type: Character.

Receives a return code.

Identifies a comma-separated list of optional property names. Specify any of the following property names, or specify '' to indicate that no properties are to be applied:

    ARCHIVE_PATH, CHANNEL_STORE, COLLECTION_URL, CORRELATIONID, 
    ENCODING, FOLDER_PATH, FROM, FTP_PASSWORD, FTP_USER, 
    GENERATED_NAME, HTTP_PASSWORD, HTTP_PROXY_URL, HTTP_USER,

    REPLYTO, SUBJECT, TARGET_VIEW_NAME, TARGET_VIEW_MIMETYPE, 
    TEXT_VIEWER_NAME, VIEWER_NAME

Type: Character
Function.Description5:
Specifies a value for each specified property name. The order of the property values must match the order of the property names in the properties parameter.

Type: Character or Numeric.

Specifies the name of the channel as it is defined in the SAS Metadata Repository. The channel contains a list of subscribers to whom the package will be published.

Returns the URL of the companion file.

    MIMETYPE

    input character string that specifies the target encoding for the companion 
    file. The companion file is translated into the specified encoding. An example 
    of a target encoding value is ISO-8859-1.

    MIMETYPE 
    character output parameter that identifies the MIME type of the companion 
    file. The MIME type is returned in the MIMETYPE variable. The publisher of 
    the companion file can set the user-specified MIME type after the companion 
    file is published. If the publisher does not specify the MIME type, then the 
    returned value is blank.

Function.Name: RETRIEVE_DATASET
Function.Definition: This CALL routine retrieves a data set entry from a package.
Function.Description1:
Identifies the data set entry. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description2:
Specifies the SAS library that will contain the retrieved data set. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description3:
Names the retrieved data set. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description4:
Receives a return code. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description7:
Identifies a comma-separated list of optional property names. Valid property names are as follows:

      DATASET_OPTIONS
      CSV_SEPARATOR
      CSV_FLAG

      Type: Character
Function.Description8:
Specifies one value for each specified property. The order of the values matches the order of the property names in the properties parameter. Valid property values are defined as follows:

      DATASET_OPTIONS
      character parameter SAS data set options that are to be applied to the
      retrieved data set.

      CSV_SEPARATOR
      character property that applies only when the RETRIEVE_DATASET CALL routine
      is called on a CSV file entry. When this occurs, the CSV file is transformed
      into a SAS data set. A binary CSV file is identified by a MIME type of
      application/x-comma-separated-values. Use the CSV_SEPARATOR property to
      indicate the separator to be used when creating the CSV file. The default
      separator is a comma.

      CSV_FLAG
      character property that only applies when calling the RETRIEVE_DATASET 
      CALL routine for a binary file entry. A binary CSV file is identified 
      by a MIME type of application/x-comma-separated-values. This property 
      is a CSV override flag. By default when converting this binary CSV file 
      into a SAS data set, the first line will be processed as variable names. 
      The second line will be processed as variable label names.

Type: Character

Identifies the HTML entry.

Specifies the full designation of the location that will receive the retrieved files.

Type: Character
Function.Description3:
Returns the name of the HTML body file. 

Type: Character
Function.Description4:
Returns the URL of the HTML body file.

Function.Description5:
Returns the name of the HTML frame file.

Function.Description6:
returns the URL of the HTML frame file.

Type: Character
Function.Description7:
Returns the name of the HTML contents file.

Function.Description8:
Returns the URL of the HTML contents file. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description9:
Returns the name of the HTML page file.

Type: Character
Description10:
Returns the URL of the HTML page file. 
    
Type: Character.

Describes the inserted HTML package entry. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description11:
Receives a return code. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description12:
Identifies a comma-separated list of optional property names. Valid property names are as follows:

      ENCODING
      BODY_TOTAL
      FILE_TOTAL
      COMPANION_TOTAL
      
Type: Character
Function.Description13:
Specifies one value for each specified property. The order of the values matches the order of the property names in the properties parameter. Valid property values are defined as follows:

      ENCODING
      input character string that indicates the target encoding for the retrieved 
      HTML file. An example of a target encoding value is ISO-8859-1. Refer to 
      Publish and Retrieve Encoding Behavior for further information.

      BODY_TOTAL
      numeric output parameter that returns the total number of HTML body files 
      published as part of this set.

      FILE_TOTAL
      numeric output parameter that returns the total number of all HTML files 
      published as part of this set. This includes all body, page, contents, 
      frame, and additional HTML files and companion files.

      COMPANION_TOTAL
      numeric output parameter that returns the total number of extraneous 
      HTML files that were published as part of this set.

Type: Character or Numeric

Function.Definition: Retrieves the descriptive header information for a nested package entry
Function.Description1:
Identifies the nested package entry.

Function.Description2:
Returns the identifier of the nested package. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description3:
Returns the number of entries in the nested package. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description4:
Returns a description of the nested package entry. 
    
Type: Character.
Function.Description5:
Returns the date and time that the nested package was published, in GMT format.

Type: Numeric
Function.Description6:
Returns the name/value pairs assigned to the package. Name/value pairs are site-specific; they are used for the purpose of filtering. 

Type: Character
Function.Description7:
Receives a return code.

Type: Numeric

Function.Name: RETRIEVE_PACKAGE
Function.Definition: This CALL routine retrieves descriptive header information for all packages.
Function.Description1:
Identifies the list of packages. 
    
Type: Numeric.
Function.Description2:
Specifies the transport to use when retrieving a package. Valid values include the following:

      FROM_QUEUE
      FROM_ARCHIVE
      FROM_WEBDAV

Type: Character
Function.Description3:
Specifies transport-specific information that determines the package to retrieve. When retrieving from an archive, specify the physical path and name of the archive, excluding the extension. When retrieving from a WebDAV-compliant server, specify the URL that identifies the package to retrieve. When retrieving from MSMQ queues, use the following syntax:

      MSMQ://queueHostMachineName\queueName
      
      When retrieving from MQSeries queues, use the following syntax:
        MQSERIES://queueManager:queueName 
      or
        MQSERIES-C://queueManager:queueName 
        
Type: Character
Function.Description4:
Provides the total number of packages found.

Type: Numeric
Function.Description5:
Receives a return code.

Type: Numeric
Function.Description6:
Identifies a comma-separated list of optional property names to be returned from the package. Valid property names are as follows:

      CORRELATIONID
      FTP_PASSWORD
      FTP_USER
      HTTP_PASSWORD
      HTTP_PROXY_URL
      HTTP_USER
      NAMESPACES
      QUEUE_TIMEOUT
      
Type: Character
Function.Description7:
Returns one value for each specified property. The order of the values matches the order of the property names in the properties parameter. Valid property values are defined as follows:

      CORRELATIONID
      This character string specifies retrieval of only those packages that have the
      specified correlation identifier. (Applies only to the message queue transport.)

      FTP_PASSWORD
      When retrieving with the archive transport (FROM_ARCHIVE), this character string 
      indicates the password that is used to connect to the remote host. Specify this 
      property only when the host does not accept anonymous access. (Applies to the 
      FROM_ARCHIVE property when the FTP protocol is used.)

      FTP_USER
      When retrieving with the archive transport, this character string indicates the 
      name of the user to connect to the remote host. (Applies to the FROM_ARCHIVE 
      property when the FTP protocol is used.)

      HTTP_PASSWORD
      When retrieving with the WebDAV transport (FROM_WEBDAV), this character string 
      indicates the password used to bind to the Web server. Specify this property only 
      when the Web server does not accept anonymous access. (Applies to the FROM_ARCHIVE 
      property when the HTTP protocol is used.)

      HTTP_PROXY_URL
      When retrieving with the WebDAV transport, this character string indicates the 
      URL of the proxy server. (Applies to the archive transport when the HTTP protocol 
      is used with archive specifications.)

      HTTP_USER
      When retrieving with the WebDAV transport, this character string indicates the 
      name of the user to bind to the Web server. (Applies to the FROM_ARCHIVE property 
      when the HTTP protocol is used.)

      NAMESPACES
      When retrieving with the WebDav transport, this character string lists one or 
      more namespaces that you are interested in, using the syntax shown in the 
      following example:

      a="http://www.host.com/myNamespace"
      A="http://www.host.com/myNamespace1"
      B="http://www.host.com/myNamespace2"
      
      QUEUE_TIMEOUT      
      This numeric value identifies the number of seconds for the poll timeout. 
      By default, if this property is not specified, the RETRIEVE_PACKAGE CALL 
      routine polls and returns immediately with the number of packages found, 
      if any. To override this default, specify the QUEUE_TIMEOUT property so 
      that the RETRIEVE_PACKAGE CALL routine will continue to poll for packages 
      until at least one package is found on the queue or until the timeout 
      occurs, whichever occurs first.

Type: Character or Numeric

Function.Description3:

Type: Numeric.
Function.Description4:
Identifies a comma-separated list of optional property names. Valid property names are as follows:

    ENCODING
    
Type: Character
Function.Description5:
Specifies one value for each specified property. The order of the values must match the order of the property names in the properties parameter. Valid property values are defined as follows:

      ENCODING

Type: Character

Function.Name: SYSMACEXEC
Function.Definition: The %SYSMACEXEC function returns the number 1 if the macro is currently executing. Otherwise, if the macro is not executing, the number 0 is returned.
Function.Description1: The name of a macro or a text expression that yields the name of the macro.

Function.Name: SYSMACEXIST
Function.Definition: The %SYSMACEXIST function returns the number 1 if a definition for the macro exists in the WORK.SASMACR catalog. If there is not a macro definition, the returned value is 0.
Function.Description1: The name of a macro or a text expression that yields the name of the macro.

Function.Name: SYSMEXECDEPTH
Function.Definition: Returns the nesting depth of macro execution from the point of the call to %SYSMEXECDEPTH.
Function.Description1: No parameters are required.

Function.Name: SYSMEXECNAME
Function.Definition: Returns the name of the macro executing at a requested nesting level.
Function.Description1:
The nesting level at which you are requesting the macro name.
   0 open code
  >0 nesting level

Function.Name: GRDSVC_ENABLE
Function.Definition: Enables or disables one or all SAS sessions on a grid.
Function.Description1:
Specifies one or all server sessions to be enabled or disabled for grid execution. 
The identifier is specified as follows:

  server-ID
    specifies the name of a SAS/CONNECT server session to be enabled or disabled for grid execution.
  _ALL_
    specifies that all SAS sessions are enabled or disabled for grid execution.
Function.Description2:
Optional Arguments:
    
  SASAPPSERVER=server-value | SERVER=server-value | RESOURCE=server-value
    specifies the name of a SAS Application Server that has been defined in the SAS Metadata Repository.
    The SAS Application Server contains the definition for the logical grid server that defines the grid 
    environment.

  WORKLOAD=workload-value
    identifies the resource for the job to be executed on the grid. This value specifies an additional
    resource requirement for which Platform Suite for SAS selects the appropriate grid nodes.

  JOBNAME=job-name-macro-variable
    specifies the macro variable that contains the name that is assigned to the job that is executed 
    on the grid.

  JOBOPTS=job-opts-macro-variable
    specifies the macro variable that contains the job options. The job option name/value pairs are
    assigned to job-opts-macro-variable.

  "" | "
    disables grid execution for the specified server ID or all server sessions.

Function.Name: GRDSVC_GETADDR
Function.Definition: Reports the IP address of the grid node on which the SAS session was chosen to execute.
Function.Description1:
Identifies the server session that is executing on the grid. The identifier can be 
specified as follows: 

      ""| "
        is an empty string that is used to refer to the computer on which the function is executing.

      server-ID
        specifies the server session that is executing on a grid.

Function.Name: GRDSVC_GETINFO
Function.Definition: Reports information about the grid environment.
Function.Description1:
Specifies the server session or the SAS Application Server whose details you want to have reported
to the SAS log. The identifier is specified as follows:

    server-ID
      reports details about the specified server ID. The details that are returned by the GRDSRV_INFO
      function reflect the arguments that are specified in the GRDSVC_ENABLE function.
      Requirement:A server-ID cannot exceed eight characters.

    _ALL_
      reports details about all server IDs to the SAS log. The details that are returned by the
      GRDSRV_INFO function reflect the arguments that are specified in the GRDSVC_ENABLE function.

    SASAPPSERVER=SAS-application-server | SERVER=SAS-application-server | SERVER=SAS-application-server
      reports information about the specified SAS Application Server to the SAS log.

    _SHOWID_
      lists each server session and its status: enabled for grid execution, enabled for SMP execution, or disabled.

Function.Name: GRDSVC_GETNAME
Function.Definition: Reports the name of the grid node on which the SAS grid server session was chosen to execute.
Function.Description1:
Identifies the server session that is executing on the grid. The identifier can be 
 specified as follows:

  "" | "
    is an empty string that is used to refer to the computer at which the statement is executed.

  server-ID
    specifies the server session that is executing on a grid.
    You use the same server-ID that you used to sign on to a server session using the RSUBMIT
    statement or the SIGNON statement.

    If the function is used in a DATA step, enclose server-ID in double or single quotation marks.

Function.Name: GRDSVC_NNODES
Function.Definition: Reports the total number of job slots that are available for use on a grid.
Function.Description1:
argument:     
  SASAPPSERVER= | SERVER= | RESOURCE=SAS-application-server 
    specifies the name of the SAS Application Server that has been defined in the SAS Metadata 
    Repository. 

option:
  WORKLOAD=workload-value 
    identifies the resource for the type of job to be executed on the grid. This value specifies 
    the workload requirements for which Platform Suite for SAS selects the grid nodes that contain 
    these resources. 
    
    The specified workload value should match one of the workload values that is defined in the 
    SAS Application Server in the SAS Metadata Repository. 
    
    Requirement:If you specify WORKLOAD=, you must also specify the SASAPPSERVER= option. 
    Workload values are case sensitive.
  
Example:
%let numofnodes=%sysfunc(grdsvc_nnodes(sasappserver=SASApp; workload=em));

Function.Name: KVERIFY
Function.Definition: Returns the position of the first character unique to an expression.
Function.Description1: Is text or a text expression that you want to examine for characters that do not exist in excerpt.
Function.Description2: Is text or a text expression that defines the set of characters that %KVERIFY uses to examine source.

Function.Name: KTRIM
Function.Definition:
Trims trailing blanks. If the argument contains a special character or mnemonic operator, 
listed below, use %QKTRIM.
Function.Description1: Text string or text exprression

Function.Name: QKTRIM
Function.Definition:
Trims trailing blanks. If the argument contains a special character or mnemonic operator, 
listed below, use %QKTRIM.
Function.Description1: Text string or text exprression

Function.Name: QKLOWCAS
Function.Definition:
Changes uppercase alphabetic characters to their lowercase equivalents. If the argument 
might contain a special character or mnemonic operator, listed below, use %QKLOWCAS.
Function.Description1: Text string or text exprression

Function.Name: KLOWCASE
Function.Definition:
Changes uppercase alphabetic characters to their lowercase equivalents. If the argument 
might contain a special character or mnemonic operator, listed below, use %QKLOWCAS.
Function.Description1: Text string or text exprression

Function.Name: COT
Function.Definition: Returns the cotangent.
Function.Description1:
Specifies a numeric constant, variable, or expression and is expressed in radians.
    
Restriction: argument cannot be 0 or a multiple of PI.

Function.Name: CSC
Function.Definition: Returns the cosecant.
Function.Description1:
Specifies a numeric constant, variable, or expression and is expressed in radians.

      Restriction: argument cannot be 0 or a multiple of PI.

Function.Name: DOSUBL
Function.Definition:
Imports macro variables from the calling environment, and exports macro variables back to the 
calling environment.
Function.Description1: Specifies a text string.

Function.Name: FCOPY
Function.Definition:
Copies records from one fileref to another fileref, and returns a value that indicates whether the 
records were successfully copied.
Function.Description1: Specifies an existing fileref from which records are to be copied.
Function.Description2: Specifies an existing fileref to which records are to be copied.

Function.Name: SEC
Function.Definition: Returns the secant.
Function.Description1:
Specifies a numeric constant, variable, or expression and is expressed in radians. 
    
Restriction: argument cannot be an odd multiple of PI/2.

Function.Name: TYPEOF
Function.Definition: Returns a value that indicates whether the argument is character or numeric.
Function.Description1:
Can have one of the following values:
    
C
  indicates that the argument is a character value.

N
  indicates that the argument is a numeric value.

Function.Name: TZONEID
Function.Definition: Returns the current time zone ID.

Function.Name: TZONENAME
Function.Definition: Returns the current standard or daylight savings time, time zone name.

Function.Name: TZONEOFF
Function.Definition: Returns the user time zone offset.

Function.Name: TZONES2U
Function.Definition: Converts a SAS date time value to a UTC date time value.
Function.Description1: Specifies a SAS datetime value.
Function.Description2:
Specifies a predefined time zone. Predefined time zone names take into consideration standard and 
daylight saving time, and rules for daylight savings time for that time zone. 

For a list of time zone names, see Appendix 2, “Time Zone IDs and Time Zone Names,” in 
SAS National Language Support (NLS): Reference Guide

Function.Name: TZONEU2S
Function.Definition: Converts a UTC date time value to a SAS date time value.
Function.Description1: Specifies a UTC date time value.
Function.Description2:
Specifies a region/area value that is defined by SAS. When you specify a zone ID, the time zone
that SAS uses is determined by time zone name and daylight savings time rules. 

Note: Time zone IDs are compatible with Java time zone names. 

For a list of zone IDs, see Appendix 2, “Time Zone IDs and Time Zone Names,” in 
SAS National Language Support (NLS): Reference Guide

Function.Name: CLIBEXIST
Function.Definition: Returns 0 when the specified caslib name is not found and 1 when the caslib is found.
Function.Description1: A valid session name.
Function.Description2: A valid caslib name.

Function.Name: GETCASURL
Function.Definition: Returns the value for a URL for connecting to the CAS Server Monitor.
Function.Description1: If 0 parameters are specified, then the SAS SESSREF= option value is used.

Function.Name: GETLCASLIB
Function.Definition: Returns the caslib that was bound to a CAS LIBNAME engine libref in the CASLIB= option when it was assigned.
Function.Description1: Specifies the caslib name that is associated with the library reference.

Function.Name: GETLSESSREF
Function.Definition: Returns the session reference that is associated with a CAS LIBNAME engine libref.
Function.Description1: Specifies the session reference name.

Function.Name: GETLTAG
Function.Definition: Returns the tag that was associated with a CAS LIBNAME engine libref in the TAG= option when it is assigned.
Function.Description1: specifies the tag that is associated with the library reference.

Function.Name: SESSFOUND
Function.Definition:
The SAS function SESSFOUND returns 0 when not found and 1 when the session is found. This function
      only has access to sessions connected using SAS Client interfaces. To return a full set of sessions
      known to the CAS server use Proc CAS and the "listsessions" action or the CAS statement.

      CAS mySess LISTSESSIONS ;
Function.Description1: Name of the CAS session.

Function.Name: GETSESSOPT
Function.Definition: The SAS function GETSESSOPT returns the value for a Cloud Analytic Services (CAS) session option.
Function.Description1: Name of the CAS session.
Function.Description2:
A CAS session option name. You can list the session option names with this code:
      
      CAS mysess LISTSESSOPTS;

isType("<type>", value);

Function.Description2: A casl value

Function.Name: NEWTABLE
Function.Description1: Name of the new table
Function.Description2: List of column names
Function.Description3: List of types for each column
Function.Description4: Rows (of type list) to be added to the table

Function.Name: ADD_TABLE_ATTR
Function.Definition: The add_table_attr adds attributes to a table. The first parameter is the table. Then pairs of values are specified as the key and value.
Function.Description1: Name of the table to add attributes to.
Function.Description2: A specified key
Function.Description3: A specified value for key-1
Function.Description4: A specified key-n
Function.Description5: A specified value for key-n

Function.Name: DISCARD
Function.Definition: Discard the variables that are listed as arguments.
Function.Description1: Variable(s) to be discarded, separated by commas.

Function.Name: TABCOLUMNS
Function.Definition: Gets the columns for a table.
Function.Description1: Name of the table.

Function.Name: TABTYPES
Function.Definition: Gets the types for a table.
Function.Description1: Name of the table.

Function.Name: PRINTTABLE
Function.Definition: This prints a table to the specified location. This function allows better control over the output a table as compared to "print table";
Function.Description1: Name of the table to print.
Function.Description2:
fileref can be:
 o ods -- uses the default print location with ODS output when appropriate.
 o log -- uses the default print location, but do not use ODS; uses the internal format routines.
 o <name> -- uses the named fileref location for output.
 o file:<path> -- uses the given path as the location for output. This file is closed after the table has been written.
Function.Description3: Specifies the number of columns to be printed per line.

Function.Name: ADDROW
Function.Definition: Adds row to a table.
Function.Description1: Name of the table.
Function.Description2: Row (of type list) to add to the table.

Function.Name: FINDTABLE
Function.Definition: This function will search the given value for the first table it sees. This is useful when a result from an action has a table result, but you do not know the name, you just know it is there.
Function.Description1: Table result from an action.

Function.Name: TRACEBACK
Function.Definition: This will return a string consisting of the traceback from the current function.

Function.Name: DICTIONARY
Function.Definition: Returns the value of a key from a dictionary. If the value does not exist, then a 0 is returned.
Function.Description1: Name of the dictionary.
Function.Description2: Dictionary key whose value is to be determined.

Function.Name: EXISTS
Function.Definition: Determines if a key exists in a dictionary.
Function.Description1: Name of the dictionary.
Function.Description2: Dictionary key

Function.Name: READPATH
Function.Definition: This will read the contents of the file given into the variable as a string.
Function.Description1: Path of file to read.

Function.Name: SESSION
Function.Definition: Creates a session variable.
Function.Description1: Name of the CAS session.
Function.Description2: Port number
Function.Description3: Username enlosed in quotes.
Function.Description4: Number of nodes

Function.Name: SORT
Function.Definition: Returns a list sorted in ascending order.
Function.Description1: List to sort.

Function.Name: SORT_REV
Function.Definition: Returns a list sorted in desccending order.
Function.Description1: List to sort.

Function.Name: GITFN_VERSION
Function.Definition: Validate that libgit2 is available for use and if available report the version that is being used.

Function.Name: GITFN_CLONE
Function.Definition: Clone the specified repository into the target directory on SAS server.
Function.Description1: Specifies the URI of the repository, such as "https://github.com/mamonaco1973/itr.git".
Function.Description2: The path of a directory on the SAS server for the repository be cloned into.
Function.Description3: User name for a secured repository.
Function.Description4: Password for a secured repository.
Function.Description5: The path to the public ssh key file.
Function.Description6: The path to the private ssh key file.

Function.Name: GITFN_STATUS
Function.Definition: Get the number of status objects associated with the local repository.
Function.Description1: The path containing a cloned Git repository on the SAS server.

Function.Name: GITFN_STATUS_GET
Function.Definition: Get the attribute of a status of object that was obtained from calling GITFN_STATUS on the local repository.
Function.Description1: The Nth status object to retrieve attributes from.
Function.Description2: The path containing a cloned GIT repository on the SAS server.
Function.Description3: The attribute to retrieve. Valid attributes are PATH, STATUS and STAGED.
Function.Description4: Returns the value of the specified attribute.

Function.Name: GITFN_STATUSFREE
Function.Definition: Free the status objects associated with a repository that were acquired with GITFN_STATUS.
Function.Description1: The path containing a cloned GIT repository on the SAS server that has previously had GITFN_STATUS called.

Function.Name: GITFN_IDX_ADD
Function.Definition: Stages 1 to N number of files in preparation for commit.
Function.Description1: The path of the local Git Repository.
Function.Description2: The relative path of the first file to be staged.
Function.Description3: The status of the file. New, Modified, Deleted, Renamed, or type change.
Function.Description4: The status of the second file, etc. New, Modified, Deleted, Renamed, or type change.

Function.Name: GITFN_IDX_REMOVE
Function.Definition: Un-stages 1 to N number of files.
Function.Description1: The path of the local GIT Repository.
Function.Description2: The relative path of the first file to be staged.
Function.Description3: The relative path of the first file to be staged, etc.

Function.Name: GITFN_COMMIT
Function.Definition: Commits staged files to the local repository.
Function.Description1: The path of the local GIT Repository.
Function.Description2: Reference to update. In most cases "HEAD" should be used.
Function.Description3: Commit author's name.
Function.Description4: Commit author's email.
Function.Description5: Commit message. Used for providing some details of the commit. Displayed in commit log.

Function.Name: GITFN_PUSH
Function.Definition: Pushes commits on the local repository to the remote repository.
Function.Description1: The path of the local Git Repository.
Function.Description2: User name used for authentication.
Function.Description3: Password used for authentication.
Function.Description4: The path to the public SSH key file.
Function.Description5: The path to the private SSH key file.

Function.Name: GITFN_PULL
Function.Definition: Pulls changes from the remote repository that were pushed by other users.
Function.Description1: The path of the local Git Repository.
Function.Description2: User name used for authentication.
Function.Description3: Password used for authentication.
Function.Description4: The path to the public SSH key file.
Function.Description5: The path to the private SSH key file.

Function.Name: GITFN_COMMIT_LOG
Function.Definition: Get the number of commit objects associated with the local repository.
Function.Description1: The path containing a cloned Git repository on the SAS server.

Function.Name: GITFN_COMMIT_GET
Function.Definition: Get the attribute of a commit object that was obtained from calling GITFN_COMMIT_LOG on the local repository.
Function.Description1: The Nth commit object to retrieve attributes from.
Function.Description2: The path containing a cloned Git repository on the SAS server.
Function.Description3: The attribute to retrieve. Valid attributes are id", "author", "email", "message", "parent_ids", and "time."
Function.Description4: Returns the value of the specified attribute.

Function.Name: GITFN_COMMITFREE
Function.Definition: Free the commit objects associated with a repository that were acquired with GITFN_COMMIT_LOG.
Function.Description1: The path containing a cloned Git repository on the SAS server that has previously had GITFN_COMMIT_LOG called.

Function.Name: GITFN_DIFF
Function.Definition: Get the number of diffs between two commits.
Function.Description1: The path containing a cloned Git repository on the SAS server.
Function.Description2: The older of the two commit IDs to run the diff between.
Function.Description3: The newer of the two commit IDs to run the diff between.

Function.Name: GITFN_DIFF_GET
Function.Definition: Get the attribute of a diff object that was obtained from calling GITFN_DIFF on the local repository and between two commit ids.
Function.Description1: The Nth commit object to retrieve attributes from.
Function.Description2: The path containing a cloned Git repository on the SAS server.
Function.Description3: The attribute to retrieve. Valid attributes are File, Diff_Content, Diff_type."
Function.Description4: Returns the value of the specified attribute.

Function.Name: GITFN_DIFF_FREE
Function.Definition: Free the diff objects associated with a repository and commit ids that were generated with GITFN_DIFF.
Function.Description1: The path containing a cloned Git repository on the SAS server that has previously had GITFN_DIFF called.
Function.Description2: The commit ID of the older of the two commits.
Function.Description3: The commit ID of the newer of the two commits.

Function.Name: GITFN_RESET
Function.Definition: Function to reset the local repository to a specific commit.
Function.Description1: The path to the local GIT repository.
Function.Description2: The commit ID to reset to.
Function.Description3: Type of reset desired. HARD (reset working directory and index discard all local changes including uncommitted), MIXED (leave working directory untouched, reset index), or SOFT (leave working directory and index untouched).

Function.Name: GITFN_DEL_REPO
Function.Definition: Function to delete a local Git repository and its contents.
Function.Description1: The path to the local GIT repository.

Function.Name: GITFN_NEW_BRANCH
Function.Definition: Function to create a new Git branch.
Function.Description1: The path to the local Git repository.
Function.Description2: The id of the Git commit level to branch.
Function.Description3: The name to give the new branch.
Function.Description4: 1 if the branch name specified is already in use, replace the branch location with this commit level.

Function.Name: GITFN_DEL_BRANCH
Function.Definition: Function to delete a Git branch.
Function.Description1: The path to the local Git repository.
Function.Description2: The name of the Git branch to delete.

Function.Name: GITFN_CO_BRANCH
Function.Definition: Function to check out a Git branch.
Function.Description1: The path to the local Git repository.
Function.Description2: The name of the Git branch to check out.

Function.Name: GITFN_MRG_BRANCH
Function.Definition: Function to merge a Git branch.
Function.Description1: The path to the local Git repository.
Function.Description2: The name of the Git branch to merge into the checked-out branch.
Function.Description3: The user ID that is invoking the merge.
Function.Description4: The email address of the user that is invoking the merge.

Function.Name: GITFN_DIFF_IDX_F
Function.Definition: Function to get the diff of a file that is in the index.
Function.Description1: The path to the local Git repository.
Function.Description2: The file path relative to the local repository.
Function.Description3: Out variable that holds the content of the diff.

Function.Name: GITFN_RESET_FILE Function
Function.Definition: Function to reset/discard changes of a file that is in the index.
Function.Description1: The path to the local Git repository.
Function.Description2: The file path relative to the local repository.
